commit_message:
The spec about adding parameters field for instances API

Adds a spec for supporting parameters field in protectable
instances API.

blueprint instances-parameters

Change-Id: I411ac237585e3f4899da1a0c56f63560923e57f5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/karbor refs/changes/94/377294/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Add parameters field for protectable instances API =================================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/custom-checkpoint-metadata Problem description =================== Now the resource instances only can be queried from defaut region. If there are several regions in one site/keystone, we can not query resource instances from different region endpoint. We may need a parameter for the region name. The scene of database protection: If we want to use Protectable Instances API to query database instances from vendor's backup software. We must pass some parameters about authentication to the RESTfull API of vendor's backup software. I think we should add a dict type parameter to Protectable Instances API. The key and value in parameter, which is needed for implementing some Protectable plugins. Use Cases ========= Scenario #1 User need a parameter for the region name to query resource instances from different region endpoint. Scenario #2 User uses the Protectable Instances API to query database instances from the vendor's backup software. User must provide some parameters about authentication to the RESTfull API of the vendor's backup software. A dict type parameter is needed for Protectable Instances API. And it is optional. Proposed change =============== Add a new field parameters to the params of request for Protectable Instances API. /{project_id}/protectables/{protectable_type}/instances: get: summary: Resource Instances description: | Return all the available instances for the given protectable type. parameters: - $ref: '#/parameters/projectParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/protectable_typeParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/nameFilterParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/sortParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/limitParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/markerParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/ParametersParam' The params of request: A dictionary-like object containing both the parameters from the query string and request body. Convert the data of parameters to the query string of API. For example: "parameters": { "region_name": "USA" } Add the query string about the parameters to Protectable Instances API. /{project_id}/protectables/{protectable_type}/instances?parameters=%7B%27region_name%27%3A+%27USA%27%7D Alternatives ------------ Do nothing, this is not a mission critical feature. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Add a new field parameters to the params of request for Protectable Instances API.:: /{project_id}/protectables/{protectable_type}/instances: get: summary: Resource Instances description: | Return all the available instances for the given protectable type. parameters: - $ref: '#/parameters/projectParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/protectable_typeParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/nameFilterParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/sortParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/limitParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/markerParam' - $ref: '#/parameters/ParametersParam' Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The new API will be exposed to users via the python-karborclient. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Work Items ---------- * Write API * Add to Karbor client * Write tests * Add a usage example for API Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests in Karbor and the python-karborclient. Documentation Impact ==================== Add a usage example for API. References ========== None

commit_message:
Add and document devmode.sh to wrap full-deploy.sh

This new script can be used by developer to create a full testing
environment from the master-tripleo-ci images, optionally including
changes either from a previous Zuul run or from Jenkins.

Change-Id: Ic9e182d2382ba962f6bf646e5b7b6ab356a805f1

subject: Avoid converting to unicode if not needed
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-29 01:19:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log/commit/cbb135a9b388b9f978864b7a5e038504ebaba4c5', 'message': "Avoid converting to unicode if not needed

In python3, str is already represents unicode data. The current code
called oslo.utils safe_encode irrespective of incoming message encoding
and encoded it to 'utf-8', however that resolves to a byte string.

Since the syslog module expects a message of type unicode[1]. We don't
need to encode if message is of type (unicode) in python2 and (str) in
python3.

[1] https://hg.python.org/cpython/file/tip/Modules/syslogmodule.c#l162

commit_message:
Avoid converting to unicode if not needed

In python3, str is already represents unicode data. The current code
called oslo.utils safe_encode irrespective of incoming message encoding
and encoded it to 'utf-8', however that resolves to a byte string.

Since the syslog module expects a message of type unicode[1]. We don't
need to encode if python3 is being used, since the string representation
is sequence of unicode codepoints by default.

[1] https://hg.python.org/cpython/file/tip/Modules/syslogmodule.c#l162

Change-Id: Id40854d6b762b2d639afd7168ddb3a1e728d13d7

commit_message:
Default use_stderr to False

While defaulting use_stderr to True might be a useful development
default, it is not useful for operators. Operators using systemd,
upstart, or any of these kinds of services, will find that if they
specify --log-file they will have two copies of the same logs on their
disk:

- one in the service log (e.g., /var/log/upstart)
- one in the log file they specify with --log-file

Instead of operators having to disable stderr log in every
configuration, we should just default it to False here.

Closes-bug #1588051

Change-Id: I85f8670d98d03101888fb7bb0c89eb809719b4e8

commit_message:
Show flavor description in the App configuration wizard

Show them in the description section right under the Flavor field
title (as quota usages + predicted increment progress bar).

Change-Id: I3f303176f255b32fd706659f7abdbd494c25d8ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/40/386540/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_flavor_description(flavor): description = '{name} ({ram}MB RAM, {vcpus} VCPUS' if flavor.disk: description += ', {disk}GB root disk' if flavor.ephemeral: description += ', {ephemeral}GB ephemeral' if flavor.swap: description += ', {swap}GB swap' description += ')' return description.format(**flavor.to_dict()) self.choices = [(flavor.name, get_flavor_description(flavor)) for flavor in flavors] self.choices.append((flavor.name, get_flavor_description(flavor)))
deleted_lines: self.choices = [(flavor.name, flavor.name) for flavor in flavors] self.choices.append((flavor.name, flavor.name))

commit_message:
Provide Murano Apps mocks

Current set of mocks covers the following UI API calls:

* GET /apps?limit=10
* GET /apps/?limit=10&packageOffset=<packageId>&appOffset=<appFqn>

Due to issues with asynchronously getting json with stubbed data and
initializing $httpBackend expectations simultaneously in the
module.run() phase, stubbed data was itself implemented as an Angular
service (though it's ugly).

Implements blueprint: schema-driven-ui
Change-Id: I3f91ad6d73674a8a15d1fd809713414fad95f353

subject: Compress murano-dashboard css assets within a common context
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-23 15:10:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard/commit/18a941b8934c8892420d8ea8dd1cd8e8c81a15ac', 'message': "Compress murano-dashboard css assets within a common context

This patch finishes the rework of murano-dashboard assets by
reorganizing css files:
* now they are scss files to use the @import statement;
* each page's set tof dedicated css rules is an @import nested under
  that page body-id, which is set in the corresponding template;
* css rules which do not have explicit use are @imported under
  #murano-common id which is set for all non-specific templates;
* specific templates still have all the css rules from 'common' murano
  set.

The above solution is not ideal, but would allow to use a single css
file for murano-dashboard, and remove custom css rules at some point
in future.

Closes-Bug: ##1603307
Change-Id: Id850063987f7980763a473eb27881bea6938d071

commit_message:
Compress murano-dashboard css assets within a common context

This patch finishes the rework of murano-dashboard assets by
reorganizing css files:
* now they are scss files to use the @import statement;
* each page's set to dedicated css rules is an @import nested under
  that page body-id, which is set in the corresponding template;
* css rules which do not have explicit use are @imported under
  #murano-common id which is set for all non-specific templates;
* specific templates still have all the css rules from 'common' murano
  set.

The above solution is not ideal, but would allow to use a single css
file for murano-dashboard, and remove custom css rules at some point
in future.

Closes-Bug: #1603307
Change-Id: Id850063987f7980763a473eb27881bea6938d071

commit_message:
Compress murano-dashboard JS scripts within a common context

Post-compressor signal relies on a presence of the 'THEME' key in
template context, which is very likely missing due to murano-dashboard
compressing its assets in its own way, without delegating this task to
openstack_dashboard base.html template.

This patch moves all murano-dashboard JS scripts to ADD_JS_FILES
setting and gets rid of murano_base.html template which sole purpose
is including these scripts.

Change-Id: I408e383fa2139dd183550e35f2c74559708b0369
Partial-Bug: #1603307

commit_message:
Move all logic related to the package upload to a separate function

This will allow to call this function both from legacy Django wizard
process_step() method, and as a separate REST API call (backed by
Django as of now) to be used by new Angular 'Import Package' wizard.

Change-Id: Idc32d3acec4dffee007df1398ddc7b617abfde91
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/24/323424/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def noop(*args, **kwargs): pass class Messages(object): def __init__(self, handlers): for key, handler in handlers.items(): setattr(self, key, handler) def _handle_upload_exception(request, original_e): exc_info = sys.exc_info() reason = '' if hasattr(original_e, 'details'): try: error = json.loads(original_e.details).get('error') if error: reason = error.get('message') except ValueError: # Let horizon operate with original exception raise exc_info[0], exc_info[1], exc_info[2] msg = _('Uploading package failed. {0}').format(reason) LOG.exception(msg) exceptions.handle( request, msg, redirect=reverse('horizon:murano:packages:index')) @catalog_views.update_latest_apps def _update_latest_apps(request, app_id): LOG.info('Adding {0} application to the' ' latest apps list'.format(app_id)) def upload_package(request, form_data, _messages=None): import_type = form_data['import_type'] data = {} all_upload_data = {} if _messages is None: _messages = Messages({'success': noop, 'error': noop, 'warning': noop}) f = None base_url = packages_consts.MURANO_REPO_URL if import_type == 'upload': pkg = form_data['package'] f = pkg.file elif import_type == 'by_url': f = form_data['url'] elif import_type == 'by_name': name = form_data['repo_name'] version = form_data['repo_version'] f = muranoclient_utils.to_url( name, version=version, path='apps/', extension='.zip', base_url=base_url, ) try: package = muranoclient_utils.Package.from_file(f) name = package.manifest['FullName'] except Exception as e: if '(404)' in e.message: msg = _("Package creation failed." "Reason: Can't find Package name from repository.") else: msg = _("Package creation failed." "Reason: {0}").format(e) LOG.exception(msg) _messages.error(request, msg) raise exceptions.Http302( reverse('horizon:murano:packages:index')) def _ensure_images(name, package): try: imgs = muranoclient_utils.ensure_images( glance_client=glance_client, image_specs=package.images(), base_url=base_url) for img in imgs: msg = _("Trying to add {0} image to glance. " "Image will be ready for deployment after " "successful upload").format(img['name'], ) _messages.warning(request, msg) log_msg = _("Trying to add {0}, {1} image to " "glance. Image will be ready for " "deployment after successful upload") \ .format(img['name'], img['id'], ) LOG.info(log_msg) all_upload_data['images'].append(img) except Exception as e: msg = _("Error {0} occurred while installing " "images for {1}").format(e, name) _messages.error(request, msg) LOG.exception(msg) reqs = package.requirements(base_url=base_url) glance_client = glance.glanceclient(request, version='1') original_package = reqs.pop(name) all_upload_data['dependencies'] = [] all_upload_data['images'] = [] for dep_name, dep_package in six.iteritems(reqs): _ensure_images(dep_name, dep_package) try: files = {dep_name: dep_package.file()} package = api.muranoclient(request).packages.create( data, files) _messages.success( request, _('Package {0} uploaded').format(dep_name) ) _update_latest_apps( request=request, app_id=package.id) all_upload_data['dependencies'].append(package) except exc.HTTPConflict: msg = _("Package {0} already registered.").format( dep_name) _messages.warning(request, msg) LOG.exception(msg) except Exception as e: msg = _("Error {0} occurred while " "installing package {1}").format(e, dep_name) _messages.error(request, msg) LOG.exception(msg) continue # add main packages images _ensure_images(name, original_package) # import main package itself try: files = {name: original_package.file()} package = api.muranoclient(request).packages.create( data, files) _messages.success(request, _('Package {0} uploaded').format(name)) _update_latest_apps(request=request, app_id=package.id) all_upload_data['package'] = package except exc.HTTPConflict: msg = _("Package with specified name already exists") LOG.exception(msg) exceptions.handle( request, msg, redirect=reverse('horizon:murano:packages:index')) except exc.HTTPInternalServerError as e: _handle_upload_exception(request, e) except exc.HTTPException as e: reason = muranodashboard_utils.parse_api_error( getattr(e, 'details', '')) if not reason: raise LOG.exception(reason) exceptions.handle( request, reason, redirect=reverse('horizon:murano:packages:index')) except Exception as original_e: _handle_upload_exception(request, original_e) return all_upload_data def process_step(self, form): step_data.update( upload_package(self.request, form.cleaned_data, _messages=messages)

"Reason: {0}").format(e) LOG.exception(msg) messages.error(self.request, msg) raise exceptions.Http302( reverse('horizon:murano:packages:index')) def _ensure_images(name, package): try: imgs = muranoclient_utils.ensure_images( glance_client=glance_client, image_specs=package.images(), base_url=base_url) for img in imgs: msg = _("Trying to add {0} image to glance. Image will be ready for " "deployment after successful upload")\ .format(img['name'], img['id'],) LOG.info(log_msg) step_data['images'].append(img) except Exception as e: msg = _("Error {0} occurred while installing " "images for {1}").format(e, name) messages.error(self.request, msg) LOG.exception(msg) reqs = package.requirements(base_url=base_url) glance_client = glance.glanceclient(self.request, version='1') original_package = reqs.pop(name) step_data['dependencies'] = [] step_data['images'] = [] for dep_name, dep_package in six.iteritems(reqs): _ensure_images(dep_name, dep_package) try: files = {dep_name: dep_package.file()} package = api.muranoclient(self.request).packages.create( data, files) messages.success( self.request, _('Package {0} uploaded').format(dep_name) ) _update_latest_apps( request=self.request, app_id=package.id) step_data['dependencies'].append(package) except exc.HTTPConflict: msg = _("Package {0} already registered.").format( dep_name) messages.warning(self.request, msg) LOG.exception(msg) except Exception as e: msg = _("Error {0} occurred while " "installing package {1}").format(e, dep_name) messages.error(self.request, msg) LOG.exception(msg) continue # add main packages images _ensure_images(name, original_package) # import main package itself try: files = {name: original_package.file()} package = api.muranoclient(self.request).packages.create( data, files) messages.success(self.request, _('Package {0} uploaded').format(name)) _update_latest_apps(request=self.request, app_id=package.id) step_data['package'] = package except exc.HTTPConflict: msg = _("Package with specified name already exists") LOG.exception(msg) exceptions.handle( self.request, msg, redirect=reverse('horizon:murano:packages:index')) except exc.HTTPInternalServerError as e: self._handle_exception(e) except exc.HTTPException as e: reason = muranodashboard_utils.parse_api_error( getattr(e, 'details', '')) if not reason: raise LOG.exception(reason) exceptions.handle( self.request, reason, redirect=reverse('horizon:murano:packages:index')) except Exception as original_e: self._handle_exception(original_e)

commit_message:
Implement basic features of NG Packages table

* New drawer table of packages with magic search filtering by Name and
  Type
* Two actions implemented: Import Package and Delete Package

All needed Django REST API endpoints were implemented along the
way. The location of angular murano services is changed to
app/core/openstack-service-api/murano.service.js, to make it aligned
with other OpenStack services in standard NG Horizon dashboard.

Change-Id: I0109221992686c5a93d172f47d3b47d7b0d6b897

commit_message:
Update Protection Plugin Spec

Change activities into hooks, and split the pre hook into prepare_begin
and prepare_finish, in order to enable a scenario like:
1. VM quiesce
2. Volume snapshot
3. VM Unquiesce
4. Volume Backup
5. Volume delete snapshot

Change-Id: Ide80a6de2bd60961af14bd5ea226bbf355d8e19e

commit_message:
Switch to xenial: Cinder

Move gate-cinder-dsvm-apache to Xenial. Run older branches on trusty.

Note that the job is non-voting, remove the condition for it and add
instead a -nv suffix.

Change-Id: Idd5254d651a09fd67519ef70c7cefee3605f6391

commit_message:
Fix render of transaction summary

* do not display time_start and time_end transaction attributes
  if they are not specified
* display transaction name instead of graph_type
  of graph_type is not specified

Closes-Bug: #1647609

Change-Id: I29144644bb4c144cb09781f190294f6ad3cc5f4b

commit_message:
Remove the -d flag to libvirtd when using systemd

If using systemd the -d flag will cause the service to always run
and the service start/stop will not properly manage the daemon.

This should make sure the behavior is not changed when using
upstart.

Change-Id: I9d9d98c92b977965b73c10ce37e4b8896723f2bf
Closes-Bug: 1647637

commit_message:
Fix import method to follow community guideline

Instead of "from i18n import _
            from i18n import _LE"
this style "from i18n import _, _LE" is recommended as community guideline [1].
[1]http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#real-world-import-order-examples

Change-Id: I1d11f7954db33244a4810944c04173e535ab674e

commit_message:
HyperVClusterDriver: ignores non-nova instances

If a failover occurs for a non-nova instance, the
HyperVClusterDriver will now ignore that instance.

Closes-Bug: #1646804

Change-Id: If523bba8339d557bc50be17f83404d06882fe9f8
(cherry picked from commit de567defd2d3b599b9449d415a80ff4e1ebfeb4c)

commit_message:
Add toggle 'dashed' to 'generate_uuid' function

Enable 'generate_uuid' function to generate uuid with dashes or not,
because some projects use uuid with dashes while some others not.

Change-Id: I6f213ea47de5713a79b5e0dccf486a7bba88f853
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils refs/changes/88/398788/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def generate_uuid(use_hex=False): if use_hex: return str(uuid.uuid4().hex)

commit_message:
Use ExtensionDescriptor from neutron-lib

Adopt the class rehomed in https://review.openstack.org/389825

This change impacts subprojects that use ExtensionDescriptor from
neutron core. All subprojects should switch to using the class
directly from neutron-lib.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: I0da90fb9d27a0a2008b60e56ed69bc9b9ae63c3e

subject: libvirt: virtlogd: use virtlogd for char devices
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-01 09:43:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d24f0c11fa15ea829016e2e159f59f29c2bb37ef', 'message': 'WIP: use the logd sub-element for char devices

After the char device config objects creation for guests are refactored,
this change makes actual usage of the "logd" sub-element for char devices.

WIP:
* C: use logd as replacement for the log file during creation - DONE
* R: read from this source for the "get_console_output" driver API
* U: renaming of instances shouldn't affect the read operation.
     live-migration from older hosts need to be considered.
* D: the log file should be deleted
* L: N/A

blueprint libvirt-virtlogd

Change-Id: I7bab3c0474da63ab283dac5963a520995cea41d2
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-01 14:19:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/04de352e9a294244f8813dfc149889b8e0188a82', 'message': 'WIP: use the logd sub-element for char devices

After the char device config objects creation for guests are refactored,
this change makes actual usage of the "logd" sub-element for char devices.

WIP:
* C: use logd as replacement for the log file during creation - DONE
* R: read from this source for the "get_console_output" driver API
* U: renaming of instances shouldn't affect the read operation.
     live-migration from older hosts need to be considered.
* D: the log file should be deleted
* L: N/A

blueprint libvirt-virtlogd

Change-Id: I7bab3c0474da63ab283dac5963a520995cea41d2
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-06-03 15:21:38.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/00b3643688bf66359a37d818253a6bf563db8af6', 'message': 'libvirt: virtlogd: use the logd sub-element for char devices

After the char device config objects creation for guests are refactored,
this change makes actual usage of the "logd" sub-element for char devices.
The two REST APIs ``os-getConsoleOutput`` and ``os-getSerialConsole`` can
now be satisfied at the same time. This is valid for any combination of:
* char device element: "console", "serial"
* char device type: "pty", "tcp"

blueprint libvirt-virtlogd

Change-Id: I7bab3c0474da63ab283dac5963a520995cea41d2

'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2016-06-28 16:12:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/50bb38faf43aef8d7c2e5296adb82dc683cf7e7f', 'message': 'libvirt: virtlogd: use virtlogd for char devices

This change makes actual usage of the "logd" sub-element for char devices.
The two REST APIs ``os-getConsoleOutput`` and ``os-getSerialConsole`` can
now be satisfied at the same time. This is valid for any combination of:
* char device element: "console", "serial"
* char device type: "pty", "tcp"
As we will have rotated "console.log" files, we have to check for them
and read them from youngest to oldest until we have read enough bytes.
There is also no need to create multiple different device types anymore.
If we have a tcp device, we don't need the pty device anymore. The logging
will be done in the tcp device.

blueprint libvirt-virtlogd
Closes-Bug: 832507

Change-Id: I7bab3c0474da63ab283dac5963a520995cea41d2

commit_message:
libvirt: virtlogd: use virtlogd for char devices

This change makes actual usage of the "logd" sub-element for char devices.
The two REST APIs ``os-getConsoleOutput`` and ``os-getSerialConsole`` can
now be satisfied at the same time. This is valid for any combination of:
* char device element: "console", "serial"
* char device type: "tcp", "pty"
There is also no need to create multiple different device types anymore.
If we have a tcp device, we don't need the pty device anymore. The logging
will be done in the tcp device.

Implements blueprint libvirt-virtlogd
Closes-Bug: 832507
Change-Id: I7bab3c0474da63ab283dac5963a520995cea41d2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/323765/33 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(host.Host, 'has_min_version', return_value=True) @mock.patch('nova.console.serial.acquire_port') @mock.patch('nova.virt.hardware.get_number_of_serial_ports', return_value=1) @mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver.libvirt_utils, 'get_arch',) def test_guest_config_char_device_logd(self, mock_get_arch, mock_get_number_serial_ports, mock_acquire_port, mock_host_has_min_version): """Test the behavior of virtlogd char devices for a guest. Two factors are important to get the range of possible test cases: * the cpu architecture of the host * the enablement of the "serial console" feature Assumed that the host has the minimum libvirt/qemu versions, it results in 4 test cases: | serial console enabled | cpu_arch | yes | no | ----------------------------------- X86_64 | 1) | 2) | S390X | 3) | 4) | Expected outcome: 1) "serial" tcp device with logd sub-element; no "file" char device 2) "serial" pty device with logd sub-element; no "file" char device 3) "console" tcp device with logd sub-element; no "file" char device 4) "console" pty device with logd sub-element; no "file" char device """ drvr = libvirt_driver.LibvirtDriver(fake.FakeVirtAPI(), True) def _get_host_caps(host_arch): cpu = vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestCPU() cpu.arch = host_arch caps = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCaps() caps.host = vconfig.LibvirtConfigCapsHost() caps.host.cpu = cpu return caps instance = objects.Instance(**self.test_instance) test_cases_input_output = { (arch.X86_64, True): ("tcp", vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestSerial), (arch.X86_64, False): ("pty", vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestSerial), (arch.S390X, True): ("tcp", vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestConsole), (arch.S390X, False): ("pty", vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestConsole), } for input, output in six.iteritems(test_cases_input_output): guest = vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuest() mock_get_arch.return_value = input[0] caps = _get_host_caps(input[0]) self.flags(enabled=input[1], group='serial_console') drvr._create_and_append_char_devices("qemu", guest, instance=instance, flavor=None, image_meta=None, caps=caps) device = guest.devices[0] self.assertEqual(output[0], device.type) self.assertIsInstance(device, output[1]) self.assertIsInstance(device.log, vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestCharDeviceLog) self.assertEqual("off", device.log.append) file_path = "/var/log/libvirt/qemu/%s-serial0.log" % instance.name self.assertEqual(file_path, device.log.file) # negative tests mock_host_has_min_version.return_value = False for input, _ in six.iteritems(test_cases_input_output): guest = vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuest() mock_get_arch.return_value = input[0] caps = _get_host_caps(input[0]) self.flags(enabled=input[1], group='serial_console') drvr._create_and_append_char_devices("qemu", guest, instance=instance, flavor=None, image_meta=None, caps=caps) for device in guest.devices: self.assertIsNone(device.log)

commit_message:
Fix render of transaction summary

* do not display time_start and time_end transaction attributes
  if they are not specified
* display transaction name instead of graph_type
  of graph_type is not specified

Closes-Bug: #1647609

Change-Id: I29144644bb4c144cb09781f190294f6ad3cc5f4b

commit_message:
Fix duplicate declaration

User configures Username(root) and Home directory(/root) in
Operating System Access, and will throw the error that
Credentials_file[/root/openrc] is already declared in deployment.

Change-Id: I6f437550edd78af372e5f52b55663beab86edfee
Closes-Bug: #1636472
(cherry picked from commit 12769a9127b438c324a2c4189a7db61aa3f958d2)

Should be a Hash.') unless args[0].is_a?(Hash) raise(Puppet::ParseError, 'Wrong common_cred_params. Should be a Hash.') unless args[1].is_a?(Hash) raise(Puppet::ParseError, 'Wrong users. Should be a Hash.') unless args[2].is_a?(Hash) cred_users, common_cred_params, users = args cred_users.inject({}) do |result, el| home_dir, owner = el.first, el.last if users.has_key?(owner) result[home_dir] = common_cred_params.dup.update({'owner' => owner, 'group' => owner, 'require' => "User[#{users[owner]}]"}) else result[home_dir] = common_cred_params.dup.update({'owner' => owner, 'group' => owner}) end result end end end

commit_message:
Remove allow_pagination and allow_sorting config options

They were deprecated in Newton. This patch cleans them up.

Note: it does not mean that the features will not work anymore. On the
contrary, now API will consistently sort and paginate for plugins that
honour the relevant sorting/pagination parameters.

Note2: base resource controller still allows to pass
allow_pagination=False and allow_sorting=False parameters to disable the
features if a registered plugin does not support the features yet.

Change-Id: I5fd30b20f645846d9366740372c4815c4b33e2eb
Related-Bug: #1566514

commit_message:
Add Spec Review Process policy

This is migrating the existing process documented in the wiki [1] into
a policy document, as suggested during the Nov 29 weekly
meeting. Hopefully it will make the document easier to find for
newcomers, and survive the upcoming wiki removal.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TripleO/SpecReviews

Change-Id: I683433cb8e28f20e71ada3097253bd0df52328c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/64/406264/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================= Spec Review Process ========================= Document the existing process to help reviewers, especially newcomers, understand how to review specs. This is migrating the existing wiki documentation into a policy. Problem Description =================== Care should be taken when approving specs. An approved spec, and an associated blueprint, indicate that the proposed change has some priority for the TripleO project. We don't want a bunch of approved specs sitting out there that no community members are owning or working on. We also want to make sure that our specs and blueprints are easy to understand and have sufficient enough detail to effectively communicate the intent of the change. The more effective the communication, the more likely we are to elicit meaningful feedback from the wider community. Policy ====== To this end, we should be cognizant of the following checklist when reviewing and approving specs. * Broad feedback from interested parties. * We should do our best to elicit feedback from operators, non-TripleO developers, end users, and the wider OpenStack community in general. * Mail the appropriate lists, such as opentack-operators and openstack-dev to ask for feedback. Respond to feedback on the list, but also encourage direct comments on the spec itself, as those will be easier for other spec reviewers to find. * Overall consensus * Check for a general consensus in the spec. * Do reviewers agree this change is meaningful for TripleO? * If they don't have a vested interest in the change, are they at least not objecting to the change? * Review older patchsets to make sure everything has been addressed * Have any reviewers raised objections in previous patchsets that were not addressed? * Have any potential pitfalls been pointed out that have not been addressed? * Impact/Security * Ensure that the various Impact (end user, deployer, etc) and Security sections in the spec have some content. * These aren't sections to just gloss off over after understanding the implementation and proposed change. They are actually the most important sections. * It would be nice if that content had elicited some feedback. If it didn't, that's probably a good sign that the author and/or reviewers have not yet thought about these sections carefully. * Ease of understandability * The spec should be easy to understand for those reviewers who are familiar with the project. While the implementation may contain technical details that not everyone will grasp, the overall proposed change should be able to be understood by folks generally familiar with TripleO. Someone who is generally familiar with TripleO is likely someone who has run through the undercloud install, perhaps contributed some code, or participated in reviews. * To aid in comprehension, grammar nits should generally be corrected when they have been pointed out. Be aware though that even nits can cause disagreements, as folks pointing out nits may be wrong themselves. Do not bikeshed over solving disagreements on nits. * Implementation * Does the implementation make sense? * Are there alternative implementations, perhaps easier ones, and if so, have those been listed in the Alternatives section? * Are reasons for discounting the Alternatives listed in the spec? * Ownership * Is the spec author the primary assignee? * If not, has the primary assignee reviewed the spec, or at least commented that they agree that they are the primary assignee? * Reviewer workload * Specs turn into patches to codebases. * A +2 on a spec means that the core reviewer intends to review the patches associated with that spec in addition to their other core commitments for reviewer workload. * A +1 on a spec from a core reviewer indicates that the core reviewer is not necessarily committing to review that spec's patches. * It's fine to +2 even if the spec also relates to other repositories and areas of expertise, in addition to the reviewer's own. We probably would not want to merge any spec that spanned multiple specialties without a representative from each group adding their +2. * Have any additional (perhaps non-core) reviewers volunteered to review patches that implement the spec? * There should be a sufficient number of core reviewers who have volunteered to go above and beyond their typical reviewer workload (indicated by their +2) to review the relevant patches. A "sufficient number" is dependent on the individual spec and the scope of the change. * If reviewers have said they'll be reviewing a spec's patches instead of patches they'd review otherwise, that doesn't help much and is actually harmful to the overall project. Alternatives & History ====================== Only use blueprints, which have no history, comment authorship or easy way to comment, making design discussions very difficult. Use the mailing list to discuss designs, which makes evolution on the initial design difficult to follow, and gets unwiedly and hard to follow as threads grow larger. Implementation ============== Author(s) --------- Primary author: james-slagle (from the wiki history) Other contributors: jpichon Milestones ---------- None Work Items ---------- Once the policy has merged, an email should be sent to openstack-dev referring to this document. References ========== * Original documentation: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/TripleO/SpecReviews Revision History ================ .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Ocata - Migrated from wiki .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Add default-tenant-network-type config option

- Add default-tenant-network-type config option to allow the default
  network type for a tenant network to be set

- Fix rendering of overlay-network-type so that an empty string is
  valid

Change-Id: Ib2325d273a0dd5e637f36113b951130387902777
Closes-Bug: 1533651

commit_message:
Glance rolling upgrades

This spec provides a gap analysis of what is required for the Glance
project to assert the various rolling upgrade tags and specifies the
actions necessary to close the gaps.

Change-Id: I40c2b85e9d9a806d528d5be5d97ca8a730631463
Co-authored-by: Hemanth Makkapati <hemanth.makkapati@rackspace.com>
Co-authored-by: Brian Rosmaita <brian.rosmaita@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/89/331489/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================ Rolling upgrades ================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/rolling-upgrades This spec provides a gap analysis of what is required for the Glance project to assert the ``assert:supports-rolling-upgrade`` tag and specifies the actions necessary to close the gaps. Problem description =================== The requirements for asserting the ``assert:supports-rolling-upgrade`` tag are listed in [GOV1]_. They are: * The project is already tagged as ``type:service``. * Glance status: done * The project has already successfully asserted the ``supports-upgrade`` tag. * Glance staus: done * The project has a defined plan that allows operators to roll out new code to subsets of services, eliminating the need to restart all services on new code simultaneously. * Glance status: The key issue is how to handle database changes required for release N while release N-1 code is still running. We outline a strategy by which this may be accomplished below. The release N-1 nodes can be replaced by taking them out of load balancer rotation and allowing them to drain, and then shutting them down. * Full stack integration testing with services arranged in a mid-upgrade manner is performed on every proposed commit to validate that mixed-version services work together properly. * Glance status: needs to be implemented Proposed change =============== We propose a strategy to implement database changes in such a way that a rolling upgrade may be accomplished within the confines of a single release. Some other OpenStack services that have addressed this problem have chosen to make database changes over a sequence of releases, but we believe that given the structure of Glance and typical usage patterns, database changes can be made and finalized within a single release. Such an approach is preferable for an open source project in which the cast of characters may change considerably from cycle to cycle. We first describe the upgrade strategy at an abstract level and then provide a detailed example of how this will work for a change that will be occurring in the Newton release. Consider the case where a database change is made such that data stored in "the old column" in release N-1 will be stored in "the new column" in release N. A rolling upgrade from release N-1 to release N can be divided into several phases: #. Pre-upgrade: Release N-1 code is running, using the old column. #. Initial schema migration: The database schema is modified to include the new column. #. The Compatabilty Phase: both release N-1 and release N code are running simultaneously. Release N-1 has no idea that an upgrade is occurring, but the release N code is running in *compatibility mode*. During this phase, both releases will read from and write to the old column. Thus any data updates made by release N code will be available to release N-1 code, and vice-versa. During this phase, the release N code nodes are being brought online as the release N-1 nodes are taken offline. The Compatabilty Phase ends when there are no longer any N-1 nodes running. #. The Data Consistency Phase: only release N code is running. During this phase, the release N code will be transitioned into *consistency mode*. Thus, some nodes will be running in compatabilty mode (reading and writing to the old column) while the nodes in *consistency mode* will be reading and writing to the new column, with a *update sensitive* read from the new column and a *fallback read* to the old column. The update sensitive read is required because the nodes in compatability mode write to the old column while the nodes in consistency mode write to the new column. Thus when a consistency mode node reads from the new column and finds a value, it needs to make sure that a newer value hasn't been written to the old column by a node still in compatability mode. One strategy for enabling update sensitive reads is to introduce a temporary column in which consistency mode nodes record the time of a write to the new column. When a consistency mode node does a read from the new column and finds a value, before using the value, it does a comparison between the update time of the row and the update time recorded in the temporary column; if the row's update time is more recent, a fallback read into the old column is performed. #. Background data migration phase: After all nodes are in consistency mode, data migration from the old column to the new column occurs, using an update sensitive read of the new column to ensure the correct value is recorded in the new column for each row. Once all data has been migrated, the release N code is using the new column exclusively. #. Final schema migration: The old column is removed from the database. At this time, the new column may have its nullability constraint adjusted and a default value set. #. Upgrade completion: the nodes are taken out of consistency mode. At this point, all release N features are available. Example ------- To understand how this would work in action, consider the following example of a Glance database change proposed for Newton. The "old column": Mitaka (release N-1): boolean ``is_public`` column in images table. This column has nullable=False and default=False. The "new column": Newton (release N) : enum (or string ... key point is it's a different data type) ``visibility`` column in images table. This column can have one of the values 'public', 'private', 'shared', 'community'. After the final schema migration phase has completed, this column would have nullable=False, and default='private'. (During the compatability and consistency phases, this column will probably have nullable=true.) Using the proposed strategy, the database upgrade would proceed as follows. #. Pre-upgrade: Version N-1 code read/write to ``is_public``. #. Initial schema migration: Add the ``visibility`` and the ``new_update`` (for use with update-sensitive reads) columns. #. The Compatability phase: Start some nodes running version N code in compatibility mode. The version N code will read/write to ``is_public``. Here's an analysis of database activity during the compatibility phase. * Write operations * The v1 API * nothing to worry about, has no concept of ``visibility`` * The v2 API #. ``visibility`` set to ``public`` * N-1: will put '1' in is_public * N: will put '1' in is_public #. ``visibility`` set to ``private`` * N-1: will put '0' in is_public * N: will put '0' in is_public #. ``visibility`` set to ``community`` * N-1: call will fail at API level, will never hit the database * N: will raise an exception until the Upgrade Completion phase #. ``visibility`` set to ``shared`` * N-1: call will fail at API level, will never hit the database * N: will write '0' in ``is_public``; this will allow image sharing to continue to work properly on the release N-1 nodes as well as the v1 API on all nodes. (It will also allow image sharing to work correctly on the release N code, given the adjustments described below.) * Read operations * The v1 API * Since the ``is_public`` column is being populated correctly, current reading should work fine * The v2 API #. Public image. In this case, ``is_public`` == 1. * N-1: sqlalchemy layer converts to ``visibility`` == ``public`` in the model * N: same as N-1 #. Private image. In this case, ``is_public`` == 0. * N-1: sqlalchemy layer converts to ``visibilty`` == ``private`` in the model. This is sufficient for the N-1 code to handle image sharing correctly. * N: when ``is_public`` == 0, the sqlalchemy layer checks to see if the image has no members; if so, it sets ``visibilty`` to ``private`` in the model. #. Community image. * N-1: cannot create a community image in N-1, so this situation does not arise. * N: You cannot create a community image until the Upgrade Completion phase, so this situation does not arise. #. Shared image. * N-1: sqlalchemy layer converts to ``visibility`` == ``private`` in the model; that the image is shared is determined elsewhere. * N: when ``is_public`` == 0, the sqlalchemy layer checks to see if the image has at least one member; if so, it sets ``visibilty`` to ``shared`` in the model, which will allow the release N code to handle sharing correctly. * All N-1 nodes are allowed to drain and then they are stopped. At this point, all nodes online are running release N in compatibility mode. #. The Data Consistency phase. Only release N code is running. All nodes start out in compatability mode; during this phase, all nodes are transisitioned into consistency mode. The code performs an update sensitive read from the ``visibility`` column (as described above), with a fallback read to the old column if the value in the new column is null. Fallback read cases: * if ``is_public`` == 1, then ``visibility`` is set to ``public`` in the model * if ``is_public`` == 0, then: if the image has any members, then ``visibilty`` is set to ``shared`` in the model; otherwise ``visibility`` is set to ``private`` in the model * any API call setting ``visibility`` to ``community`` failed while in compatibility mode (and will continue to fail while the code is in consistency mode), so there is no need to worry about translating any value in ``is_public`` into community visibility. #. Background data migration phase: Crawl the 'images' table. Do an update sensitive read of the ``visibility`` column; and if necessary, set the value of the ``visibility`` column using the same logic as the fallback read described above. Do this in such a way that the table isn't locked and race conditions on the row are avoided. #. Final schema migration: Remove the ``is_public`` column (and any auxiliary columns introduced for the upgrade). #. Upgrade completion: All nodes are taken out of consistency mode. All release N features are now available. Alternatives ------------ Nova: Unlike Glance, Nova has to deal with a large number of compute nodes which may take a long time to upgrade, and hence it requires a more complicated upgrade scheme. Cinder: Keystone: Neutron: Data model impact ----------------- Changes which require modifications to the data model often have a wider impact on the system. The community often has strong opinions on how the data model should be evolved, from both a functional and performance perspective. It is therefore important to capture and gain agreement as early as possible on any proposed changes to the data model. Questions which need to be addressed by this section include: * What new data objects and/or database schema changes is this going to require? * What database migrations will accompany this change? * How will the initial set of new data objects be generated? For example if you need to take into account existing images, or modify other existing data, describe how that will work. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ There will be more comparisons and database filed accesses than normal during consistency mode. The background data migration will consume extra database resources, but this can be mitigated if the migration script is carefully written. Other deployer impact --------------------- Each phase of the migration requires operator intervention. Developer impact ---------------- Any developer working on a feature that requires database changes must write additional code to support the rolling upgrade strategy outlined in this document. By confining the database changes to a single release, however, developers of release N+1 do not have to worry about completing procedures begun during the migration of release N-1 to N. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: rosmaita hemanthm Other contributors: nikhil Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= In order to assert the rolling upgrades tag, we must implement the following: Full stack integration testing with services arranged in a mid-upgrade manner is performed on every proposed commit to validate that mixed-version services work together properly. This testing must be performed on configurations that the project considers to be its reference implementations. The arrangement(s) tested will depend on the project (i.e. should be representative of a meaningful-to-operators rolling upgrade scenario) and available testing resources. At least one representative arrangement must be tested full-stack in the gate. Documentation Impact ==================== * Documentation of general information for Glance rolling upgrades. * Documentation of configuration options for putting the code into the various modes and running the database scripts. References ========== .. [GOV1] https://governance.openstack.org/reference/tags/assert_supports-rolling-upgrade.html

Refactor test_credentials

Do not reuse client's domain, create a new one to be used only by the
test, which is destroyed later.

commit_message:
XenServer patch

As OpenStack + XenServer deployment is not that common as KVM. This
patch contains class parameters update and all parameters to
allow configure OpenStack with XenServer more easily. It covers
parameters needed for non-DHCP network deployment with flat network
config injection (same as Rackspace).

Deployment guides for OpenStack + XenServer can be found here:

https://www.citrix.com/blogs/2015/11/30/integrating-xenserver-rdo-and-neutron/
http://openstack-xenserver.readthedocs.io/en/latest/

Change-Id: Ib8185f6dcd6153473e820973049f234f7f7d3cfd

commit_message:
[UG] Add description of `delete graph` command

This patch:

- adds the description of the `fuel2 delete graph` command
  to the corresponding sub-section of Fuel CLI section;
- adds steps on how to delete a deployment workflow
  to the Manage workflows sub-section of the Maintain your
  env section;
- changes the following parameters as preferable in
  fuel2 CLI where applicable: '--env' to '-e',
  '--type' to '-t', '--release' to '-r', '--plugin' to '-p',
  '--all' to '-a', '--cluster' to 'c';
- renames 'graph' to 'workflow';
- fixes noticed typos.

Change-Id: I2e88436792d812ba60f5189c4a572d680ed0ae21
Closes-Bug: #1633773
(cherry picked from commit 51ac33c003e683bd169191410408b8a2f0c56985)

commit_message:
tests: fix breakage of oslo.db 4.15.0

new oslo.db force test_migration to use the provision system
that we don't want. Since we create and cleanup the engine ourself.
We can mock the provisioning system like we do for oslo.db<=4.14.0 for
self.db.

Related-bug: #1647280

Change-Id: Ida22e8a58a8f7b2fbe6ba9dc32a6dcb0d99d7c61

commit_message:
Heat Resource Type Versions

Heat Resource types can have a version property so that
we can support multiple versions across deployments.
Resource types could have a default version, and
if it's not provided the default would be used.

Change-Id: I628681f1978b2750b27088cc96541ff2d1194582
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/01/398601/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================== Heat Resource Type Versions =========================== Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/heat-resource-type-versions Problem description =================== Currently, a vendor can extend the capabilities of the orchestration service by writing their own heat resource plug-ins. However, this feature currently does not support the notion of versions. As a vendor rolls out new version of a resource type, a new resource type with a new name will need to be created or at the minimum be backward compatible. Proposed change =============== Adding support of ``version`` property for custom heat resource types. Currently, a vendor who wishes to provide versions to a heat resource type can do so by appending the version number to the type name. For example, .. code-block:: yaml old_resource: type: Vendor::ResourceTypeV2 The proposed change is to add ``version`` property. For example, .. code-block:: yaml new_resource: type: Vendor::ResourceType version: 2.0 Resources would be given an optional ``version`` attribute. This will let multiple versions of the resource exist and be used simultaneously. Currently, when a resource is registered, a resource_mapping() function returns a map of the resource template name and the implementation class. To add support of versioning, we propose to return a map of the resource template name to another map of a version and the version's implementation class. For example, .. code-block:: python def resource_mapping(): return { 'My::Custom::Plugin': MyResourceClass } becomes, .. code-block:: python def resource_mapping(): return { 'My::Custom::Plugin': {'1.1': MyResourceClass}} The version's format will have a major part and a minor part. When creating a resource, if the ``version`` is not specified, we can assume to use the highest version registered. If a ``version`` specified does not exist or is invalid, the API will return a 400 or 406 error. Alternatives ------------ We can suffix the version number to the resource type, e.g., ``Vendor::ResourceTypeV2.4``. This requires new resource name change as new versions become available. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee(s): * Julian Sy - syjulian Other contributor(s): * Jin Li - JinLi Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: ocata-3 Work Items ---------- * Implement versioning capabilities to resource type. * Add unit testing Dependencies ============ None. References ========== `Barcelona summit discussion <https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/heat-ocata-api-microversions>`_

subject: WIP: Add configuration for discovery dhcp

commit_message:
WIP: Add configuration for discovery dhcp

Adds configuration variables to be used for discovery dhcp. These are
used to write out a dnsmasq.conf by oac.

The discovery-dhcp element is at I258e9243b7be1a02779f3e90a8e03ace01abc4d2
this will eventually be used to write out the dnsmasq.conf installed
by that element.

Change-Id: I848c350b8a346a2ffa6470b4ad476fe116532ddc

commit_message:
Use default domain context when listing multidomain users

In Identity->Users, if multidomain support is enabled and no domain
context has been explicitly selected, attempting to list the users will
make Keystone return a 401 Unauthorized error, which in turn results
in Horizon assuming that the token expired and logging out the user.

Because it's not possible to distinguish that error from a legitimate
token expiry (it should probably be 403 Forbidden instead), I'm adding
a check before we call Keystone, and use the default domain for the
context if none was selected by the user.

In addition, all the tests assumed that no context is selected, and only
worked because they mocked the Keystone calls (real Keystone returns an
error in that case). So I had to make the tests use a default domain
instead.

Change-Id: I2a02ce11c76176bd99c8d67ed10fc09696fddcf6
Closes-Bug: #1415588

commit_message:
Replace 'parse_int_param' with 'get_positive_int'

The old utility function was designed for API request validation
(mainly). Now with API requests validated using jsonschema, the old
function becomes heavy-weight. This patch is an optimization.

Change-Id: Ieaeb068924984e1cb8d9763383dbc62903b1ea47

added_lines: def test_parse_positive_int(self): cases = {1: 1, 2: 2, '1': 1, '2': 2} for value, expected in cases.items(): res, actual = utils.parse_positive_int(value) self.assertTrue(res) bad_values = ['foo', {}, [], -1, 1.5, 0.2, None] for value in bad_values: res, actual = utils.parse_positive_int(value) self.assertFalse(res) self.assertEqual(0, actual)
deleted_lines: def test_parse_int(self): name = 'param' cases = {0: 0, 2: 2, '0': 0, '2': 2} for value, expected in cases.items(): actual = utils.parse_int_param(name, value) # A None should be returned directly actual = utils.parse_int_param(name, None) self.assertIsNone(actual) for value in (2, '2'): self.assertTrue(utils.parse_int_param(name, value, allow_zero=False)) for value in (0, '0'): self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidParameter, utils.parse_int_param, name, value, allow_zero=False) for value in (-1, '-2'): self.assertTrue(utils.parse_int_param(name, value, allow_negative=True)) for value in (-1, '-2'): self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidParameter, utils.parse_int_param, name, value) for value in (1, 6): self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidParameter, utils.parse_int_param, name, value, lower_limit=2, upper_limit=5)

commit_message:
Don't install zaqarclient on upgrades

The zaqarclient installation doesn't harm anything but at the same time
it's not necessary anymore, so we can remove it. It was needed only for
K->L upgrade.

Change-Id: Ia04ff06efeb940958003ba59477986a1462376f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/72/335872/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add unit tests for doctor federation file

This patch adds unit tests for the doctor symptoms located in the
federation file.

Change-Id: Ide0a0a4bad2d1749effa731111d0d36286c148a7
Partial-Bug: #1641621
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/88/407188/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.cmd.doctor import federation def test_symptom_comma_in_SAML_public_certificate_path(self): # Success Case: There is a comma in path to public certification file self.config_fixture.config(group='saml', certfile='file,cert.pem') self.assertTrue( federation.symptom_comma_in_SAML_public_certificate_path()) # Failure Case: There is no comma in the path self.config_fixture.config(group='saml', certfile='signing_cert.pem') self.assertFalse( federation.symptom_comma_in_SAML_public_certificate_path()) def test_symptom_comma_in_SAML_private_key_file_path(self): # Success Case: There is a comma in path to private key file self.config_fixture.config(group='saml', keyfile='file,key.pem') self.assertTrue( federation.symptom_comma_in_SAML_private_key_file_path()) # Failure Case: There is no comma in the path self.config_fixture.config(group='saml', keyfile='signing_key.pem') self.assertFalse( federation.symptom_comma_in_SAML_private_key_file_path())

commit_message:
Add volume_connectors and volume_targets to task

Adding volume_connectors and volume_targets to the task object
to allow for matching the existing model leveraged by ports and
portgroups which allows for simplified storage_interface use.

Change-Id: Iea1af5b939ba9374feef56ce22ae718eb6c7a672
Partial-Bug: #1559691
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/96/366196/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: task.volume_connectors Storage connectors belonging to the Node task.volume_targets Storage targets assigned to the Node self.volume_connectors = objects.VolumeConnector.list_by_node_id( context, self.node.id) self.volume_targets = objects.VolumeTarget.list_by_node_id( context, self.node.id) self.volume_connectors = None self.volume_targets = None

commit_message:
Define common function to download files

Add function to download file from specific URL that's integrated with
OFFLINE flag.
It will download file only when it not exists or there is newer version
of same file. Useful for local development.
Move installing and cleaning Go to separate function.

Change-Id: Ia2b5efc0d82366c6ad75e688512df9606cb2f1ed

service with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/367982

commit_message:
mistral-dashboard: added action executions screens

 * Added 3 new action executions screens: index, overview, and update dialog
 * Added "type" attribute to task screens, followed by a corresponding link
 * Fixed breadcrumbs issue in detail screens following Horizon Newton change
 * Added state label design to detail screens
 * Added design to boolean fields

 * Screenshots: http://pho.to/AXApU

Implements blueprint: mistral-dashboard-action-execution-screens
Implements blueprint: dashboard-detail-screens-improvements
Partially implements blueprint: refactor-execution-link-in-task-executions-screens
Closes-Bug: #1642246

Change-Id: I4c270b2b23d548d4e1cb7e8507e804e44e27c88f

commit_message:
Correct minor issues in test schema

The JSONSchema used to validate the token response had a couple of
issues:

- The domain property schema was wrapped in a domain property
- 'bind' in optional was always present already so no need to add it
  again.

Change-Id: I512e5a041c6ba96fbff71fac1bfdde02f888a582

commit_message:
Fix local check factory bug

The landing of [1] introduced an issue whereupon local
checks were registered after the options had already been
populated with pep8 checks (see patch); resulting in the
checks not running. Instead, the checks can be "refreshed"
by getting them from a pep8 StyleGuide and updating on
the options.

A unit test is also included that verifies the options are updated
with the latest checks from a pep8 StyleGuide object.

This change was in my workspace/testing for [1], but somehow
was left out of the patch commit. I'm still investigating what
happened and am very humbled.

If reviewers don't agree to this patch, then we should revert
[1] and re-release openstack-dev/hacking. Note that openstack
projects should not yet be consuming hacking 0.13.0 [2].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/397940/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/405583/

Change-Id: I081a0551c663ae661fd3c1b527ddc492bef9b2b1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/hacking refs/changes/72/405672/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # refresh the option checks based on what was registered above style_guide = pep8.StyleGuide() options.physical_checks = style_guide.get_checks('physical_line') options.logical_checks = style_guide.get_checks('logical_line') options.ast_checks = style_guide.get_checks('tree')

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-06 11:38:31.000000000', 'files': ['puppet/services/services.yaml', 'docker/services/services.yaml', 'overcloud.j2.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/5d3a418e89c962e7f88327c11bae08d223976a59', 'message': 'Add {global,service}_merged_config_settings

These are is a config_settings hashes with a twist: they're deep-merged
to the first level (arrays get merged, lists get joined). This can be
helpful for avoiding workarounds whenever we need to collect some
information from multiple services, e.g.:

data:
  - firewall_rules:
      '10_abc':
        dport: 80
    ceph_pools: ['admin', 'openstack']

  - firewall_rules:
      '20_def':
        dport: 8080
    ceph_pools: ['manila']

will get processed into:

{
    "ceph_pools": [
        "admin",
        "openstack",
        "manila"
    ],
    "firewall_rules": {
        "10_abc": {
            "dport": 80
        },
        "20_def": {
            "dport": 8080
        }
    }
}

Change-Id: I2aeed772a3358c862b2142f3134a7869814164e3
'}]
commit_message:
Add {global,service}_merged_config_settings

These are is a config_settings hashes with a twist: they're deep-merged
to the first level (arrays get merged, lists get joined). This can be
helpful for avoiding workarounds whenever we need to collect some
information from multiple services, e.g.:

data:
  - firewall_rules:
      '10_abc':
        dport: 80
    ceph_pools: ['admin', 'openstack']

  - firewall_rules:
      '20_def':
        dport: 8080
    ceph_pools: ['manila']

will get processed into:

{
    "ceph_pools": [
        "admin",
        "openstack",
        "manila"
    ],
    "firewall_rules": {
        "10_abc": {
            "dport": 80
        },
        "20_def": {
            "dport": 8080
        }
    }
}

Change-Id: I2aeed772a3358c862b2142f3134a7869814164e3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/69/407469/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Deep-merge global config settings - yaql: expression: $.data.where($ != null).reduce($1.mergeWith($2), {}) data: {% for r in roles %} - get_attr: [{{r.name}}ServiceChain, role_data, global_merged_config_settings] {% endfor %}

Remove dependency on import from neutron

Removes import from plugin constants from neutron. This will help
the neutron move to neutron-lib.

Start to use states from neutron-lib

Replace common plugin states with those from neutron-lib
This will enable us to remove them soon.

commit_message:
Revert "Enable zaqar ui when zaqar enabled"

This reverts commit 9fc5157cc7172eea6cd875692a44e13cab1b8226.

zaqar role is not implemented and there is no enable_zaqar variable,
too.

Change-Id: If40fdf8d672ee5e0b375513364734f245fa1d682
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/61/407461/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: enable_zaqar: "no"

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-02 21:18:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7d84e7c79227f90ec52ea150aa3091ab5b3aa080', 'message': 'WIP: avoid set error state when resize fail

Change-Id: Ib15a6a0b0b33d73113a9c63f3fee601ec666c12e
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-12-04 11:36:39.000000000', 'files': ['nova/compute/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b467bf3b3cd3b80e03c8e51ef72bbd2ff0f66808', 'message': "avoid set error state if resize fail in some case

sometimes, it's no need to set instance to ERROR state
when some pre-action of resize failed, such as info not found

Change-Id: Ib15a6a0b0b33d73113a9c63f3fee601ec666c12e
"}]
commit_message:
avoid set error state if resize fail in some case

sometimes, it's no need to set instance to ERROR state
when some pre-action of resize failed, such as info not found
state incorrect etc as we didn't really start the resize
yet, so we can return state back to ACTIVE.

Change-Id: Ib15a6a0b0b33d73113a9c63f3fee601ec666c12e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/406365/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # TODO(chaochin) Remove this until v5 RPC API # Code downstream may expect extra_specs to be populated since it # is receiving an object, so lookup the flavor to ensure this. if (not instance_type or not isinstance(instance_type, objects.Flavor)): instance_type = objects.Flavor.get_by_id( context, migration['new_instance_type_id']) network_info = self.network_api.get_instance_nw_info(context, instance) migration.status = 'migrating' with migration.obj_as_admin(): migration.save() instance.task_state = task_states.RESIZE_MIGRATING instance.save(expected_task_state=task_states.RESIZE_PREP) self._notify_about_instance_usage( context, instance, "resize.start", network_info=network_info) compute_utils.notify_about_instance_action(context, instance, self.host, action=fields.NotificationAction.RESIZE, phase=fields.NotificationPhase.START) bdms = objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid( context, instance.uuid) block_device_info = self._get_instance_block_device_info( context, instance, bdms=bdms)
deleted_lines: # TODO(chaochin) Remove this until v5 RPC API # Code downstream may expect extra_specs to be populated since it # is receiving an object, so lookup the flavor to ensure this. if (not instance_type or not isinstance(instance_type, objects.Flavor)): instance_type = objects.Flavor.get_by_id( context, migration['new_instance_type_id']) network_info = self.network_api.get_instance_nw_info(context, instance) migration.status = 'migrating' with migration.obj_as_admin(): migration.save() instance.task_state = task_states.RESIZE_MIGRATING instance.save(expected_task_state=task_states.RESIZE_PREP) self._notify_about_instance_usage( context, instance, "resize.start", network_info=network_info) compute_utils.notify_about_instance_action(context, instance, self.host, action=fields.NotificationAction.RESIZE, phase=fields.NotificationPhase.START) bdms = objects.BlockDeviceMappingList.get_by_instance_uuid( context, instance.uuid) block_device_info = self._get_instance_block_device_info( context, instance, bdms=bdms)

commit_message:
Fix render of transaction summary

* do not display time_start and time_end transaction attributes
  if they are not specified
* display transaction name instead of graph_type
  of graph_type is not specified

Closes-Bug: #1647609

Change-Id: I29144644bb4c144cb09781f190294f6ad3cc5f4b

added_lines: --- - name: Starting tacker container kolla_docker: action: "start_container" common_options: "{{ docker_common_options }}" image: "{{ tacker_image_full }}" name: "tacker" volumes: - "{{ node_config_directory }}/tacker/:{{ container_config_directory }}/:ro" - "/etc/localtime:/etc/localtime:ro" - "kolla_logs:/var/log/kolla/"
